Title: New insights in abdominal pain in Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): A MRI study
Abstract: © 2015 De Cobelli et al.Introduction: Abdominal pain in PNH has never been investigated by in-vivo imaging studies. With MRI, we aimed to assess mesenteric vessels flow and small bowel wall perfusion to investigate the ischemic origin of abdominal pain. Materials and Methods: Six PNH patients with (AP) and six without (NOP) abdominal pain underwent MRI. In a blinded fashion, mean flow (MF, quantity of blood moving through a vessel within a second, in mL·s<sup>-1</sup>) and stroke volume (SV, volume of blood pumped out at each heart contraction, in mL) of Superior Mesenteric Vein (SMV) and Artery (SMA), areas under the curve at 60 (AUC<inf>60</inf>) and 90 seconds (AUC<inf>90</inf>) and K<sup>trans</sup> were assessed by two operators. Results: Mean total perfusion and flow parameters were lower in AP than in NOP group. AUC<inf>60</inf>: 84.81 ± 11.75 vs. 131.73 ± 18.89 (P< 0.001); AUC<inf>90</inf>: 102.33 ± 14.16 vs. 152.58 ± 22.70 (P< 0.001); K<sup>trans</sup>: 0.0346 min<sup>-1</sup> ± 0.0019 vs. 0.0521 ± 0.0015 (P = 0.093 duodenum, 0.009 jejunum/ileum). SMV: MF 4.67 ml/s ± 0.85 vs. 8.32 ± 2.14 (P = 0.002); SV 3.85 ml ± 0.76 vs. 6.55 ± 1.57 (P = 0.02). SMA: MF 6.95 ± 2.61 vs. 11.2 ± 2.32 (P = 0.07); SV 6.52 ± 2.19 vs. 8.78 ± 1.63 (P = 0.07). We found a significant correlation between MF and SV of SMV and AUC<inf>60</inf> (MF:ρ = 0.88, P < 0.001; SV: ρ = 0.644, P = 0.024), AUC<inf>90</inf> (MF: ρ = 0.874, P< 0.001; SV:ρ = 0.774, P = 0.003) and K<sup>trans</sup> (MF:ρ = 0.734, P = 0.007; SV:ρ = 0.581, P = 0.047). Conclusions: Perfusion and flow MRI findings suggest that the impairment of small bowel blood supply is significantly associated with abdominal pain in PNH.
